questions.question: You are suspecting a case of delayed puberty in a 15-year-old boy. To assess puberty in thispatient, what is the first sign you would look for?

As an intern, you are currently posted in the Paediatric endocrinology OPD where you seemultiple cases of girls having precocious puberty. The condition is defined by the onset ofsecondary sexual characteristics before the age of
questions.explanation: Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8years in girls and 9 years in boys.Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified inthe following manner:Note:Central Precocious Puberty(more common) >> Peripheral Precocious PubertyCentral Precocious Puberty(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)Due to the excess secretion ofgonadotropins (FSH and LH)from pituitaryAlways isosexual (appearanceof phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys)GirlsIdiopathic (most common)BoysCNS pathology (most common)Peripheral Precocious Puberty(Gonadotropin independent)Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gonads/adrenals.Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondarysex characters of the opposite sex).Girls Estrogenic ovarian cysts(isosexual) Congenital adrenalhyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)BoysCAH (isosexual; most common)

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about hersignificant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination,the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the mostcommon brain lesion causing this condition?
questions.explanation: Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organiccentral precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in femalesand onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive ofcentral precocious puberty.It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by-Early-onset of puberty•●Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures.Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precociouspuberty.633

questions.question: 627A young girl was referred to the paediatrician with stage IV breast development and growthacceleration seen at the age of 5 years. Her estradiol concentrations were elevated. Thesagittal MRI of the brain is as shown below. What is the treatment of choice for thiscondition?
questions.explanation: A pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle as shown in the MRI, with elevated levels ofestrogen is suggestive of a Hypothalamic Hamartoma, which is the most common brain lesioncausing central precocious puberty and is treated with GnRH agonists.Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma-•• GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice of tumour-induced Centralprecocious puberty• In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotorseizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewerrisks than neurosurgical intervention.Long-acting formulations of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are thepreparations of choice for the treatment of central precocious puberty as they maintain fairlyconstant serum concentrations of the drug for weeks or months.

questions.question: A primary school teacher notices bloodstains on the skirt of her second-grade student. Sheimmediately informs her parents and accompanies the child to the doctor on campus. Onexamination, the 7-year-old girl had blood-stained vaginal discharge, enlarged breasts andareola. Which of the following is not a cause for this condition?
questions.explanation: Vaginal bleeding with well-developed breasts before the age of 8 years is suggestive of precociouspuberty. Prader-Willi syndrome is one of the causes of delayed puberty in girls (not precociouspuberty), where there is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.Hypothalamic hamartoma, McCune-Albright syndrome and hypothyroidism are causes ofprecocious puberty.Note:In prolonged hypothyroidism, adolescents typically have delayed puberty. Younger children mightpresent with pseudo-precocious puberty, characterized by breast development and vaginalbleeding in girls and macroorchidism in boys.Elevated levels of TSH appear to interact with the FSH receptor (specificity spillover), thusinducing FSH-like effects in the absence of LH effects on the gonads. The FSH-like effect sufficesto induce estradiol secretion by the ovaries, whereas in males, testicular enlargement occurswithout substantial testosterone secretion.

questions.question: 628An incessantly crying 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her father. You observe that sheneeds support to walk and her trunk is not symmetrically aligned. There is a history ofrecurrent fractures in her limbs. She also has blood-stained vaginal discharge from a fewdays. On examination, the girl appears as shown in the image below. What is the mostprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Precocious puberty(vaginal discharge), bony lesions (polyostotic fibrous dysplasia), and cafe aulait spots, as shown in the picture, are features of McCune-Albright syndrome. There is pain dueto the multiple bony lesions and repeated fractures may result in incessant crying in the childrenand may require regular visits to the orthopaedics department.634McCune-Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by amutation of GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.Fibrous dysplasia of multiple bones (polyostotic) represents a major cause of morbidity in thissyndrome. The base of the skull and the proximal femurs are most commonly involved, but anybone can be affected. A CT scan is usually recommended even in absence of deformities. Theprognosis is favourable for longevity, but deformities, repeated fractures, pain, and occasionalcranial nerve compression may result from the bony lesions.Cardinal features:•Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia• Cafe au lait macules• Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomousovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty• Predominantly affects girls

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy on examination is found to have genital development corresponding toTanner stage 1 and his height is below the 3rd Percentile on growth charting. What is themost common cause for this condition?
questions.explanation: Failure of development of pubertal features by the age of 14 years in male is suggestive of DelayedPuberty.The most common cause of delayed puberty in males and females is a constitutional delay ingrowth and puberty. Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive ofdelayed puberty. Delayed puberty is more common in boys than in girls.

questions.question: 629Breast and papillae appear as a small mound on examination of a young girl. If you aresuspecting a case of delayed puberty, it is defined as a lack of development of secondarysexual characters beyond the age of
questions.explanation: Delayed puberty in girls is defined as lack of secondary sexual characteristics by the age of 13years or absence of menarche by the age of 16 years or within 3 years of pubertal onset.

questions.question: A child presents with features of delayed puberty. On investigating, he has decreased levels ofLH, FSH, and testosterone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This patient has low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), andtestosterone pointing towards hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and Kallman's syndrome is theonly condition in the given choices causing hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.Causes of delayed puberty:Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central)Hypogonadism is due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitarygland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production• Malnutrition, systemic diseases• Kallmann (anosmia), Prader-Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)635Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure)Hypogonadism is due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH),which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as anattempt of compensation by the body)•Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)• Androgen insensitivity syndrome• Ovotesticular dysgenesisNormal1° Failure2° FailureHYPOTHALAMUSGnRH+PITUITARYGONADSGnRH+LHFSHLHFSHLHFSHGonadotropinsNormalHyper ↑Hypo↓

questions.question: All of the following are features of Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome except
questions.explanation: Hypertension is seen in Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome.Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl is an autosomal-recessive disorder of hypogonadotropichypogonadism.Characteristic features:• Polydactyly• Obesity• Retinitis pigmentosa•Male hypogonadism• Hypertension• Mental retardation

questions.question: A female child presents with bilateral inguinal masses, which were thought to be hernias butwere found to be testes in the inguinal canals. Which karyotype would you expect to find inthe child?
questions.explanation: 636Here, this baby girl with bilateral inguinal masses (testis) probably has androgen-insensitivitysyndrome, where karyotype is 46,XY.Androgen-insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in theandrogen receptor gene that makes XY fetuses insensitive to androgens. The patientsphenotypically resemble females because a part of the testosterone is converted to estrogen, whichleads to the development of female external genitalia, normal development of breast, and femalehabitus.Patients with Klienfelter's syndrome have a karyotype of 47, XXY and can have undescendedtestis, but they have male external genitalia where the phallus tends to be smaller than average.Characteristic features:•Most common forms of male disorders of sexual differentiation (DSD).• 46 XY male child with female phenotype, present with primary amenorrhoea.• Normal male gonads, mostly undescended ones, can present as inguinal masses or hernia.•• Here, as testosterone receptors are defective, they do not act on tissues, leading to the absence ofsecondary sexual characters (absence of pubic hair and axillary hair).

questions.question: An infant was found to have elevated levels of LH. The baby has a 46, XY chromosomepattern on karyotyping and the vagina is short and ends blindly in a pouch. Which of thefollowing is false in the condition suffered by the infant?
questions.explanation: An infant with a 46, XY chromosome pattern and female external genitalia are suggestive ofAndrogen-insensitivity syndrome (AIS) where there is absent internal female genitalia.These patients have absent internal female genitalia with normal female external genitalia withthe vagina ending blindly, in a pouch and normal male gonads in the form of undescended testis(mostly) which can present as inguinal masses.In a male child (46, XY), testicular hormones are resistant to receptors, and a part of thetestosterone is converted to estrogen leading to the development of female external genitalia andeventually normal development of breast, and female habitus.Features of Androgen insensitivity syndrome at different age groups-••In infants, elevated LH levels should suggest the diagnosis of AISPrepubertal females with this disorder are often detected when inguinal masses which prove tobe testes• In older children and adults, amenorrhea is the usual presenting symptom.Note:Reifen-Stein syndrome: Males with various forms of ambiguous genitalia and undervirilization(hypogonadism, severe hypospadias, and gynecomastia). They are phenotypicallynormal-appearing males with infertility.

questions.question: A 31-year-old female delivers a term baby. On examination, it has a micropenis andunpalpable testis. She gives a history of acne from 16 weeks of gestation which worsenedthroughout pregnancy and was treated after delivery. The baby was diagnosed to have femalepseudohermaphroditism. Which of the following statements are right about the givencondition?

options.B: Female external genitalia and male internal genitalia

questions.explanation: 637Female pseudohermaphrodites are genectic females (XX genotype) with male external genitalia.Causes:•Enzyme deficiencies: 21 hydroxylase, 11 hydroxylase, and 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase(HSD) deficiencies• Maternal androgen excessMale pseudohermaphrodites are genetic males (XY genotype) with female external genitalia.Causes:•Enzyme deficiencies: 17 hydroxylase and 3-beta HSD deficiencies• Defect in androgen actionTrue hermaphroditism/ovotesticular dysgenesis: An intersex condition in which an individual isborn with ovarian and testicular tissue.

questions.question: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development?

options.B: Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
options.C: The response of testosterone to hCG is increased.

questions.explanation: Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarianand testicular tissue in the same individual. An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 ofaffected individuals.Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in femalesexual development. In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XXkaryotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the Xchromosome or another chromosome. There is a defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by theRSPO1 gene, described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD.An abnormal vagina and an underdeveloped uterus are usually present. The testes are usuallyundescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias. Upon reaching puberty, breastdevelopment, feminization, and menstruation may occur. Most affected individuals are infertile,but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible. The response of testosterone to hCG is normal orreduced.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a girl (46XX) with an enlarged clitoris is highly suggestiveof congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.Congenital adrenal hyperplasia/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessivedisorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones inthe adrenal cortex. The majority of cases of CAH are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Thisdeficiency leads to a lack of synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone, resulting in the salt-wastingform of the disease, which is the most severe form.Severe 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with symptoms including weight loss, dehydration,weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances. Accumulated steroid precursors like63817-hydroxyprogesterone, are shunted into the pathway of androgen synthesis leading to elevatedlevels of androstenedione and testosterone. This can result in abnormal genital development inaffected female fetuses during early gestation.Females may have masculinized external genitalia. This can include enlargement of the clitoris,partial or complete labial fusion, and a shared opening of the vagina and urethra (urogenitalsinus).Untreated individuals develop signs of androgen excess after birth. These signs includeaccelerated skeletal maturation, premature epiphyseal closure leading to stunted adult stature,excessive muscular development, the appearance of pubic and axillary hair, acne, and deepeningof the voice. In males, enlargement of the penis, scrotum, and prostate. In females, the clitorismay become further enlarged.Diagnosis of confirmed by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Glucocorticoid replacementwith hydrocortisone is done. In a salt-wasting crisis, fludrocortisone supplementation is given.Vaginoplasty and clitoral recession are done for females with ambiguous genitalia.639
